item.title: Interview | Shan Hai Jing, a museum and the appetite of the old
item.description: An interview with the duo of authors of the next English language publication Shan Hai Jing Code 《上古文明密码》, which today Macau has already presented, but now becomes a museum. Michael Du & Julie Oyang, the authors are currently organizing a breathless textual race through the most important piece of Chinese literature and the heaviest treasure of Chinese culture and… beyond. Julie Oyang is an art and culture critique based on Europe, commentator of Chinese culture and visual philosopher. He is a guest professor at the University of São José in Macau, China. Michael Du is a knowledgeable of the Ancient Chinese Canadian culture, holding the largest collection of Hongshan civilization in the world. He is the founder of Haikou Kiwen International Art & Culture Co. Ltd. (海口啓運國際文化藝術品有限公司) and Kiwen International Cultural Exchange (Yantai) Co.ltd (国际文化交流（烟台）有限公司). Both authors are closely involved in the operation of the China Museum of Art for Pre-Dinastic Civilizations (华夏上古文明艺术馆), which will soon open in Yantai, China. Q: In part I of the interview, we talked about the historical meaning of the former Chinese manuscript Shan Hai Jing 《山海经》, also known as the Book of Mountains and Seas, especially its universality. What follows? Michael: We have talked about how a deeper study of Shan Hai Jing can help us understand the origin of the first human civilizations on Earth. But we are makers. We are not for the written pages: we want to ensure that Shan Hai Jing is relevant and alive and making it part of the current culture. With this objective, I found a new company. The Kiwen International Cultural Exchange (Yantai) Co.ltd (启运国际文化交流（烟台）有限公司) was created after the Haikou Kiwen International Art & Culture Co. Ltd. (海口啓運國際文化藝術品有限公司) is the place Where global investigation will take place and the global exchange of knowledge will be encouraged and stimulated in the form of international delegations and high -level visitors. We know so little about the old ones, there are so many questions to ask… Julie: In fact, there is so much to do. There is so much we can do. In collaboration with the Chinese government, we are both involved in the operation of the China Art Museum for pre-Dinastic civilizations (华夏上古文明艺术馆), where Michael curates his own artifact collection, as well as private collections of Rename around the world, including all pre-doneastic civilizations, such as Hongshan, Liangzhu, Shanxingdui, HongShuihe, Shijiahe, etc. These art objects have never been exposed and were never explained by traditional historians. We understand that it is extremely important for us to provide private collectors a place where they can show their journey dedicated to seeking answers to questions about humanity. In this sense, the China Museum of Art for Pre-Dinastic Civilizations (华夏上古文明艺术馆), which should open in Yantai in April, is a unique and brilliant view. We even have the architecture to correspond to this vision. Our goal is to educate the global public in general, as well as establish a connection with the young audience in a fun way and with high quality standards. Beyond the exhibition, which will do more to make the mysterious old “alive and active” to the global audience? Julie: At this time, Michael and I are planning a parallel exhibition and a workshop in collaboration with French artist chef Gil Gonzalez-Foerster (Chinese name: 晓松). In a way, the Yantai museum is a time capsule where an old and faded memory is stored. And Gil's kitchen deals with memory, this time from these pre-Dinastic civilizations, starting from Shan Hai Jing. Being the imaginative guardian of memory, the Chinese classic contains the oldest memory in China, or even in the world. Shan Hai Jing records ancient memories in the form of mythology meditations and the most interesting facts about flora and fauna known for their magical power and powerful force that live from one extreme to the other. This seems to be the reputation of this ancient and inexhaustible text. But Shan Hai Jing is also an extraordinary recipe book! But why food? Michael: You are what you eat. Food is an essential part of everyday human life that can tell us more about the past. When a dish is no longer remembered, part of us cease to exist. Food is perhaps the most intimate and sensual memory. Perhaps this is one of the reasons why Shan Hai Jing was written: remember through food? Our curated exhibition will become more complete, more 3D, more realistic, exploring the taste of the ancients! Julie: Shan Hai Jing documents diverse gastronomic experiences, mixing natural history and food knowledge. His humanist approach makes Shan Hai Jing unique in his genre. The word Shi (食), “eat”, appears more than 160 times in the book, of the ancients. There are, however, many cases about exotic food that heals medical conditions quite familiar to modern men, but Shan Hai Jing also offers cure for conditions such as arrogance, confusion/lack of wisdom, ward off physical dangers. This is a unique culinary philosophy! Food involves the mind, not just the taste. To provoke the intellect. This deep idea is still deeply rooted in modern Chinese food. Through our exhibition, we also understand why Confucius taught his disciples that food is a virtuous gift and why the great Chinese scholarly poets were famous food lovers. We currently do not know who was the author of the mysterious Chinese classic whose imagination exceeds a thousand and one nights… Michael: The ancients were "men of appetite." Appetite can explain humanity's historical and economic landscapes more clearly than academic jargon. Speaking of economics, how is the museum economy managed? Michael: The museum is an educational organism. It is also a business. We focused on five volumes of business. The investigation mainly involves cooperation with various institutions and training programs in China. We organize courses, events and publications. This part will generate 7.6 million RMB/year. Ticket sales will generate 7.2 million RMB/year. Authenticity certification will generate 3.5 million RMB/year. We will also form art and antique auctions agents, whose program will generate 4.9 million RMB/year. In spring and fall, a large-scale auction will be held, with a conservative estimate of 50 million RMB volume by auction. This amount does not include revenues from the commission of 15% of sellers and buyers. In addition, four more themed auction games will be held annually, with a conservative estimate of 5 million RMB of turnover and 6 million RMB of auctioning commission.

item.title: António Queirós, philosopher and academic: “the West there is great ignorance” about China
item.description:
Doctorate in Philosophy of Sciences, Environmental and Environmental Ethics, António Queirós, linked to the Faculty of Letters of the University of Lisbon, regrets that the West continues to face China in the wrong way, especially in environmental issues. HM talked to António Queirós before the lecture on the subject he gave yesterday at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center in Lisbon
Will talk about the theme “The Environmental Crisis and the China Eco-Civilization Project”. What project is this? This is China's great project for the New Age. It is a concept that began to be elaborated from 2013. This idea began to be realized with different projects. Since the “New Democracy” regime, which resulted from the Chinese resistance to the occupation of Japan and the geopolitical confrontation of the countries of the axis of different democracies. This is when the Popular Republic of China is proclaimed, such as the proclamation of the “new democracy” and comes awareness of the environmental crisis worldwide by China, with the regime to evolve into the so-called “ecological socialism” From 2003. It was necessary for the country to experience a model of industrialization common to the first experiences of socialism, and especially the capitalist countries. China's fundamental thesis is that all regimes can collaborate in building a new civilization, but this implies outdoor democratic reforms that are consigned in global civilization proposals, guaranteeing peace according to the principle of indivisibility of security. But I would like to point out the moment when the United Nations (UN), representing the whole world, became aware of the existence of an environmental crisis, from the Stockholm Conference, which took place in 1972. On the part of the organs of the socialist state, citizens and parties, it began in 2003. It is strange that issues like this never be debated to the West. The ideological confrontation that comes from the Cold War did not cease with Helsinquia's agreements, and therefore there are themes that are unknown to the West because of this harmful tradition of the Cold War, which has extended, and because the media have no openness. to discuss and present the proposals that China makes. China is present and is an important actor in world meetings on environment and climate. Why do you understand that there is no discussion the West about the concept of eco-civilization? It is not discussed why the West there is great ignorance about China and the reality of the country. The only advantage I have about most people who write and talk about China is that my relationship with the country is over 50 years old. I know how China was presented to the West 50 years ago. We lived [in Portugal], a fascist regime where information came to people with great difficulty. I have seen these years to all kinds of visions about China that lacked concrete information, because the country, until reform and openness, was a closed society. But this lack of information was general in the West. I also had visions that were not reality and I began to question myself if China's historical experience is unique, without parallel in the history of society, democracy and socialism, for its historical characteristics, hermeneutics, in the sense of method, analysis, analysis of concepts and starting points, which predominates the West, does not serve. But then let's go to the concrete issue, which is the responsibilities that China has in environmental matters. Which, specifically, are… One thing is the contribution that give China, India and other countries to global warming, because they are populations that represent most of humanity. There are technologies that are themselves polluting. But if we look at this angle we ended up falsifying reality, because greenhouse gases that exist in the atmosphere have been at least 150 years ago due to European and American industrialization. In terms of historical responsibility, the US is largely responsible [for global warming], and I cite official European Union data, for example. I speak of tons of carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases emitted to the atmosphere in all these years. Because they industrialized much earlier than China. Yes, and presented an industry without this kind of environmental concerns. Therefore, this reality is hidden, which greenhouse gases have begun to pollute for 150 years and that it is not only today's contributions [which are the major causes of global warming]. Therefore, the idea that China is the main polluting country finds it wrong. In current terms China and India can be the most polluting. But they are neither in “per capita” nor historically. What is really [in the Western discourse] is that they currently contribute [to global warming]. But then we have to see the trends where we are going to walk. But if we deepen this topic we have come to even less favorable conclusions to Western policies. China's environmental history can be summed up at four periods. The first period is in the years of reform and openness, from 1978, and the fourth period is when China launches the pilot projects of ecological civilization. The process is global. Still in relation to China's responsibilities, in the first phase the West and the industrialized east carried to China the most polluting industries, because China's appeal was to industrialize and create more employment. The UN resolution that adds an article beyond the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, finally recognizes as an inalienable right of the human being to a healthy environment. This statement, the West, completely truncated, reduced to no thing, has a preamble with 30 articles in which the environmental issue is not posed. Since this statement is no longer in line with current political and social reality, it has been moving, mutilated and reduced to formal freedoms. Also ignored by the set of citizens who do not know their origin either. China is co-founder of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, a fact that is also concealed. But I also wanted to talk about the largest fallacy of the Western environmental policy. What is it? The idea that, from now on, one will protect nature. So what is done to what was destroyed? Especially in developing countries, because it was there that we sent these residues from the polluting industries and exploited all resources. No one wanted to know that, and what did China did? He assumed the leadership of the process and through his diplomacy to "act without acting," Tao's way, without violating nature, respecting the laws and dignity of things, approving the Kunming-Montreal agreement [on biodiversity]. We then have a commitment that the US probably will lie down to the rubbish crate to recover the biotypes that are destroyed, because much of the world is in environmental crisis and has so far been whistling to the side. China has a gradual view that risk factors in the environmental crisis tend to decrease with China's effort, both nationally and international. But the most remarkable issue in the idea of ​​building an ecological state in the country was the fact that, at the initiative of President XI Jinping, principles of environmental philosophy were included in the Statutes of the Chinese Communist Party, unprecedented in another Communist Party and even some ecologists. Global reformulation According to the study “Ecological Civilization in the People's Republic of China: Values, Action, and Future Needs”, by Arthur Hanson, published in 2019 by Asian Development Bank, the concept of ecological civilization “is being used by the Popular Republic of China ( RPC) to provide a coherent conceptual framework for adjustments to the development that responds to the challenges of the century XXI. It differs from sustainable development in the emphasis placed in political and cultural factors, as well as in the definition of new relationships between people and nature that allow you to live well and within the eco-environmental boundaries of planet Earth. ” In addition to reducing pollution and promoting the circular economy, for example, they are also considered “domains of finance, law, institutional reinforcement and technological innovation”, having already been defined some ideas in five-year plans approved by Beijing, highlighting If "needs in the medium term, especially until 2035, when ecological civilization, in its basic form, is expected to be fully implemented for the modernization of the RPC".

item.title: Mark O'Neil launches biographical work on Liang Sicheng and contribution to Chinese architecture
item.description:
Mark O'Neill, a journalist and author to reside in Hong Kong, published a biography of Liang Sicheng, responsible for documenting ancient Chinese architecture, which during the cultural revolution was the target of political persecution. The book written by the author of English origin, released by the publisher Joint, calls itself “Liang Sicheng: Guardian of the architectural history of China”
When did you contact Liang Sicheng's figure? When I lived in Beijing I was interested in the old part of the city, for it was like no other in the world. Liang Sicheng said the following about this old part of Beijing: “The general layout shows the traditional system of the historic cities of China, being the result of geography, political and economic conditions of Yuan, Ming and Qing dynasties. It also expresses artistic management that led to a high level of success. It served the feudal era well and also serves life very well in the new age. It may be the capital of the New Age. This in no way prevents good development. All this creativity over a long time makes us proud. ” In the 1950s, Liang and a collaborator prepared a proposal of 25,000 characters for the construction of a new administrative center in the western part of the city, to house all the ministries and official buildings and leave the old city as it was. But the new government rejected this proposal and demolished most of the old city. Built its new capital in the center of the ancient city. This broke the heart of Liang and his wife Lin Huiyin. In Beijing, I met Liang's second wife, Lin Zhu. She explained all these dramatic events. It was a stimulus to write the book. Both she and her daughter, Liang Zaibing, wrote excellent books that describe all this. They were a fundamental research material for the book. What do you consider most fascinating in Liang Sicheng's career? I greatly admire Liang's aesthetic values ​​and his meticulous work in the documentation of China's old buildings, 2,738 in total. In 1944, in the midst of the worst horrors of the Japan war against China, which killed many of his friends and family, he wrote a letter to the US military representative in Chongqing. He made a list of historic places in Nara, Kyoto and Osaka, and proposed that they be spared to destroy the American bombers. What generosity and meaning of extraordinary humanity. In 2009, Nara raised a statue in her honor. He lived during the anti-Japanese war and the terrible campaigns of the beginning of the communist period. But it maintained its meaning of mission: preserving the treasures of Chinese architecture and forming a new generation of architects and the University of Tsinghua. What are the main architectural currents, or specific buildings, which Liang helped preserve or draw attention? He and his wife [Lin Huiyin] documented 2,738 old buildings with precious, Chinese and English measurements, and caught the national and international attention to them. Without it, many could have been destroyed or dropped into the degradation process. He defined the characteristics of traditional Chinese architecture and described the architects and artisans who built it. It can be said that as intellectual, Liang Sicheng suffered persecution during the Cultural Revolution. In concrete terms, how was this period for Liang? In chapter 10, we describe the Cultural Revolution as the Liang Calvary, as was for thousands of intellectuals and party officials [Chinese Communist Party]. Liang lived and worked at the University of Tsinghua campus. The government handed the campus control to frivolous red guards. Liang was an obvious target for them because he had studied in the United States, spoke English and had many foreign friends. The persecution he suffered was so severe that he eventually led him to death. In 1966, his health was already fragile; I was 65 years old. He was forced to write “self-confessions” and to attend mass critic sessions. The red guards looted their apartment. But he did not commit any crime, he was simply an architect and teacher. The criticism was absurd. After the years of the Mao regime, two of his works were published. What do we tell us about the country's architecture? After Mao's death and the end of the cultural revolution, he was rehabilitated and his works were published in Chinese and English. Its greatest legacy is the explanation of the history of Chinese architecture, the analysis of the old buildings and the techniques used to build them. One of the most famous is the Fo Guang Si Buddhist Temple, located in the Wutai mountains in Shanxi. Liang Sicheng caught the attention of the Chinese and foreign world to this legacy. Liang Sicheng was one of the few architects of the time with foreign formation. What were the main influences revealed in the main architectural projects of the time? Liang and his wife, as well as a small number of Chinese colleagues formed abroad, brought back to China the modern architecture. He taught her at the University of Northeast in Shenyang from 1928 to 1931, and at the University of Tsinghua, from 1945 to his death, and during the Cultural Revolution, these classes became impossible. This is another important legacy - the hundreds of architects who formed and the textbooks he wrote to them. In the global memory of ancient Chinese architecture, his work was fundamental. He launched the foundations for it. Since then, many have followed their example in the investigation, both Chinese and foreigners. Liang Sicheng, an “extraordinary life” devotes to architecture According to an official note about the work, released by the publisher Joint Publishing, Liang Sicheng had "an extraordinary life." Son of Liang Qi-Chao, one of China's most famous intellectuals, Liang Sicheng grew up in Japan. Educated at the University of Pennsylvania, Liang also studied at Harvard and was greatly influenced by American architects and architecture. One of the few Chinese of his time with deep knowledge about modern architecture, Liang Sicheng returned to China in 1928 and spent more than 12 years to investigate the architecture of ancient China, continuing his work even during the years of World War II, when the years China was partially occupied by the Japanese. He published his discoveries in Chinese and English newspapers, revealing to the world for the first time the history, knowledge and beauty of Chinese architecture. After World War II, he taught at Yale University and was the representative of China in the conception of the new United Nations (UN) headquarters in New York. Post-1949 Life After 1949, he remained in Beijing as head of the Architecture Department of the University of Tsinghua. He designed the main buildings of the new communist regime, but failed to persuade President Mao Zedong to preserve the ancient city of Beijing. In the 1950s, and in the years of the Cultural Revolution, it was severely criticized. In January 1972 eventually died in the Chinese capital. With the end of the cultural revolution, his figure and reputation were rehabilitated and his own posthumously published. In 1984, his “pictorial history of Chinese architecture” was published in English by Wilma Fairbank, friend of the architect and his wife, and married to the synologist John Fairbank.

item.title: Ricardo Clara Couto, author of the documentary about Francisco de Pina | The weight of the guilt that persists
item.description: “Francisco de Pina - The Portuguese who wrote the future of Vietname” tells the story of Father Jesuit, born in Guarda in 1586, who made the romanization of the Vietnamese alphabet. The documentary, by Ricardo Clara Couto was funded by RTP2 and aired at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center How did you come across this character in Portuguese history in the East? My brother, named Filipe Pires, traveled for Vietnam for a while and when he arrived from the trip he told me that he had to know the incredible history of the Jesuit Francis of Pina who had made the romanization of the Vietnamese alphabet, providing freedom and cultural independence tremendous. I was a little skeptical at first, because I found it strange no one to know this in Portugal, but I started my research on the subject and discovered a university study of a Franco-Vietnamese teacher who teaches in Madeira. I then confirmed that the idea that my brother had brought from Vietname was correct. From there, I tried to discover the origin of this priest, the work he had done, and realize why there was so little knowledge about Francisco de Pina in Portugal. In addition to being a Jesuit missionary, can you highlight some biographical points that help you understand your legacy? In the documentary I did not have the time to be able to take a more exhaustive biographical approach. I focused on the part where he arrives at Vietname. We talk about a man with an incredible culture and a desire to acculturate and be acculturated. A man who was a musician and was easier, thus learning the Vietnamese, which is a six -tone language. Deep down, despite being a Jesuit priest, he had the first of course culture and not so much religion. This, for me, is a reason for huge admiration. For him the essential objective of evangelization was secondary, because, for him, if we could not understand the culture of Vietnam, we could not teach the Vietnamese people. It was more important to deepen local culture and language, making it possible to be able to explore the most religious part. It was also a man who had a hard time when he arrived at Vietname. Why? There were some internal wars before some local gentlemen of the regions who did not agree with the mission of the priests. This is not explored in the documentary, but in fact Francisco de Pina even made some steps [for the Jesuit mission], as the priests were not totally accepted everywhere. He eventually took refuge in a Japanese neighborhood and, from there, built his base. Francisco de Pina, like what happened to many Jesuits at the time, was training in Macau, at the College of S. Paulo. How was it influenced by this period spent in the territory? There is not much information about this time. It is known that it was indeed formed in this college, as was the case with many Jesuit priests at the time, but then went to Japan. Only then go to Vietname. So far, there was nothing of great relief in the life of Francisco de Pina, who followed the normal way. Japan was already expelling the Jesuit priests and it is in this context that goes to Vietname. The only most prominent thing about this period is that the 14 ships that left Portugal to arrive in Macau this year remained only three, and the ship where I was Pina Francisco was one of those who survived the storm. Do you consider that your great legacy was the romanization of Vietnamese? What are the great contributions of this process in linguistic terms? It is a giant contribution. If we think that even in the romanization of the language, Vietname was very dependent on the Chinese alphabet, and could not have cultural, linguistic and economic independence as well. After the romanization of the alphabet it was possible for Vietname to grow in these domains and have her own identity. The country has grown a lot to this day, because without writing a tongue passes only to the new generations of mouth in mouth, and the legacy of Francisco de Pina also remains today. The Vietnamese people are very grateful to this, and the proof is that two years ago a delegation of the Vietnammemesse Language Foundation Foundation came to Portugal and offered a monument to Guarda City Council (see Caixa) in honor of Francisco de Pina. However, I was surprised by the fact that the Vietnamese, and we talked about full -sided academics, know the story, the figure of Francisco de Pina, existing in the country several references. But in Portugal it is a little known figure. How do you explain this? I think this will have to do with the need Portugal has to make its catharsis about this period of history. Portugal was a completely different country from Africa to the East, and completely different from Africa to the Americas. But, however, there is this weight of guilt. Portugal cannot talk about this period of time, despite having a rich history between Africa and the East, but this time is not very approached because the country has not taken over what happened and, therefore, cannot talk about this period. Therefore, so much of the rich history of Portugal is unknown to the Portuguese. How was the research process for the documentary? I quickly arrived at the study of Professor Minh Ha Nguyen Lo Cicero of the University of Madeira, and with her we went to the roots of the Vietnamese language. When I discovered it was amazing, because it is part of the Vietnamese alphabet romanization triangle, as it is Franco-Vietnamese. Until recently, the official version that existed was that Alexandre de Rhodes, French Jesuit, had romanized the alphabet, later registering it in the Vatican and saying that it was a work in honor of his master, Francisco de Pina. However, the name of Francisco de Pina disappeared. From here we passed to the nationalist French official narrative that the romanization of the alphabet had been made by French because Vietname was a French colony. Then I also arrived at Professor António Morgado. The remaining contacts were made at Vietname, linguists, university professors and language specialists, especially in writing, who later joined the documentary. How would you describe the Vietname of the time of Francisco de Pina? It was very fragmented. They have a very their own culture that existed through a writing with Chinese hieroglyphics, but deals with Vietnamese, which led only 1 to 3 percent of the population to read and write. With the romanization this percentage increased exponentially, and with this the culture developed with the populations, united them more around common writing. I think this has made Vietname more modern and prepared to integrate into the rest of the world by having a more affordable language. Do you feel it will help unravel this part of the history of Portugal, as well as the history of the Jesuit mission itself? I hope so. Portugal seems to have a certain fear and shame to talk about this time, and proof of this is that this Vietnamese people came to Guard to offer a monument and practically did not come out of the subject. In addition, the representatives of the Vietname delegation were a little admired for not being received at an official level, except for the mayor of Guarda. I, who was invited by them to be present, felt a little shame of others, because Vietname came to Portugal to offer a monument and this is viewed as a secondary event, which is not. It would be important to make known this priest and this made to the country and the world, because Portugal and Vietnam have a very close and rich cultural history, as with Japan and China. But this is a little known aspect of the Portuguese people and [this documentary] can be a good opportunity for the country to make their catharsis. Vietnamese artist sculpture resembles Francisco de Pina at Guarda In November 2023, the Vietnamese Language Foundation offered the city of Guarda the sculpture “Nova Estela” by Vietnamese artist Nguyen Huy Anh. The work can be seen in the Garden of the Eduardo Lourenço Municipal Library. According to news from the agency Ecclesia, the event took place under the celebrations of the 824th anniversary of the attribution of Foral by King D. Sancho I to the city. “This is a posthumous tribute to Father Francisco de Pina, a Guarda-born Jesuit priest in 1586, whose religious path underwent a mission in Vietname, where he lived nine years of intense missionary activity, linguistics and of interculturality, ”said the Diocese of the Guard, in a statement. According to the same note, the missionary Francisco de Pina was responsible for the introduction of the Latin alphabet and diacritical signs in the transcription of the sounds and tones of the Vietnamese language, which used, in writing, Chinese characters. The priest embarked for over 400 years at the Nau de Nossa Senhora do Mount of Carmo, having completed the training at the São Paulo College in Macau and received the priestly ordination in Malaca. It was then called to the newly created Mission of the Jesuit Cchinchina, a zone that corresponds to the central part of the current Vietname. “He never came to the city where he was born and now returned in a bronze -carved boat by Vietnamese artists brought by the distant Vietname sea. From now on, Father Francisco de Pina will be in the historical memory of the guard and its inhabitants, materialized in this boat that brought him back to his city, leaving the name of the guard far, also written in Bronze letters ” , concluded the diocese.

item.title: Piménio Ferreira: “Anti-igan rhetoric has always worked in Portugal”

If you want to know what it is like to live in pure neoliberalism, know the lives of Gypsies. The group of political, social, cultural and economic power. The owner, the colonizer. This group that has been in power since it established the system of current domination. And that only makes sense within the hierarchically stratified sociopolitical model in which we live. Hence the need to end 'gentlemen' and institute a new model of society, healthy, free, without hierarchies or strata, whether of race, class or gender. The model we live in leads to the Gypsy (and not only) community to economic exclusion, removing it from access to product consumption or excluding them from its production process; political exclusion associated with lack of access to information; To education and consequently the social exclusion that is seen in inequality of access to quality community areas such as restaurants, libraries, theater, cinema, concerts, health care, etc. How do you feel a gypsy child when you realize that it is not part of a whole? Is this a disaster for self-esteem, is a priori condemnation? The question is that. Gypsy people are not “excluded from society”, by contrast, they are included in it. Even in attacking Gypsy children's self -confidence, we talk about a maintenance mechanism of this situation. But Gypsy people respond very well: with Gypsy pride. Another resistance, another aggression. Gypsy people are thus included in society. In a place that belongs to this model of modern society. And they resist and contradict the power of domination and make a point of being in the city, in the cinema, in the theater, in the gym, in all spaces. With a lot of struggle and always resisting, but they are there. Social exclusion, more than a “place outside of society”, is part of its social structure. Do you want to say that there is a collective resistance? It should also be noted how they reinvented and intensified to raise and distribute dietary goods and kits of masks/alcohol gel to the most expropriated people. Gypsies and non -Gypsies. In the anti-racist struggle, new movements emerged and their actions intensified by social networks. People forget, or do not want to value, but Gypsy action has helped determine results in the political dispute. And even in the presidential, second place was resolved by a value equivalent to the estimated number of Gypsy voters. Apart from the non -Gypsy votes that were mobilized by the action of Gypsy voters. Gypsy people are even co-considering power in the spaces of opinion, local media, social networks and party and institutional political dispute. And most importantly, in the popular Ação and alliances with other social movements. We have never stopped fighting for all means and continuing to resist. In contrast there are more and more hate speeches, from the far right in particular. What do you have to say about it? To start these speeches are historical and European. But before transforming, we need to survive. Hence two types of actions arise: transformative and survival. Due to housing and work precariousness, the subjects racialized especially the Roma nationals are the most vulnerable to COVID-19. There is essential to have actions in this area; Of all the struggles, this is the most structural, as it goes against one of the main enemies of a healthy society: the real estate speculation of this capitalist system, which places profit and goods above people and their humanization.

item.title: Motorcycling | FHO RACING WITH NEW FOCUS IN 2025
item.description:
Doubts dissipated this week. Macau's businesswoman Foye Ho's FHO Racing will continue to active in the 2025 season, but without the initially announced riders. Peter Hickman and Davey Todd are leaving and goes to a new team called 8ten Racing
According to a statement sent by FHO Racing, BMW Motorrad UK has restructured its training for the 2025 British Superbike Championship, and FHO Racing BMW will compete with a single pilot aboard a BMW M 1000 RR. German 2024 Superbike Champion and Resistance World Cup driver, Ilya Mikhalchik, will make his debut in the British competition, at a time when team owner Faye Ho, realinhas the objectives of his team “to explore new activities in sports Motorized in new markets, with the support of the BMW Motorrad Motorsport ”. Currently in his fifth year at the British Superbike Championship Paddock, Faye Ho has been a strong presence in the British competition, as well as in the popular road races, such as the Macao Grand Prix, as well as supporting several young women's pilots, helping to progress in their careers from the lower classes. Faye Ho, Stanley Ho's granddaughter and Clementina Leitão, has supported Kate Walker and Jamie Hanks-Bliott on BMW F 900 R Cup and, it seems, which will continue to support. To be Contrary to the rumors that put her from Paddock's departure, Faye Ho made it clear that she is a “great advocate of the British Superbike Championship, one of the world's most exciting and competitive competitions” and will keep her commitment to discipline. However, the territory entrepreneur now has new objectives for herself and its structure. The future will be in Asia and support for young female talents. “Given my long -term objectives, which include expanding motor sport activities in Asia and continuing to support young women in motorcycling, I realized that I can't dedicate the same time to the British Superbikes and road racing championship, I gave them since I became the owner of the team in 2021, due to the additional appointments I have in Macao, ”said Faye Ho. Another chapter This announcement has put an end to a successful partnership, particularly on the island of Man TT, between Peter Hickman, four times winner of the Macao Motorcycle Grand Prix, and Fho Racing. Hickman left some words of thanks to his now former boss. “I want to leave a huge thanks to Faye [Ho] and Fho Racing for all they have done for me over the past four years,” Hickman wrote in a Facebook social network post. “As it is normal in motorized sport, we had amazing moments and others more difficult, but Fho has always been and always will be a fundamental part of my career. I will be eternally grateful for this opportunity. ” The new 8Ten Racing team, which will be officially presented on February 26, will be mostly composed of former FHO Racing elements. Hickman and Todd will maintain the important support of BMW Motorrad UK and are expected on the big prize starting grid in November.

item.title: GT Cup | Great Bay Race gains impulse from the interior
item.description:
The GT Cup-Great Bay Race will join this year, the newly created Sro GT Cup, the latest GT competition launched in the interior of China, inspired by the GT4 class vehicles of the Macau Grand Prix
On the eve of last Christmas, Sro Motorsport Group, the entity responsible for organizing numerous races and championships, including the GT World Challenge Asia and, as the official partner of the FIA, the co-coordination of the FIA ​​GT World Cup in Macau , announced the creation of a competition for GT4 vehicles, consisting of four events in China. At the time of the announcement, only the inaugural event in Shanghai and the end in Beijing had been confirmed as part of the calendar. Almost 30 cars, representing an impressive total of ten car builders, participated in the GT Cup - Great Bay Race of 2024, a race that has become an important milestone over the weekend of the Macao Grand Prix in recent years. Indeed, no other GT4 event in Asia brings together such quantity and diversity of cars. The Balance of Performance (BOP), responsible for balancing the performance of the various participating cars, was, at the time, managed by SRO. In a statement, Benjamin Frannasovici, managing director of Sro Motorsports Asia, said: “We are enchanted, proud and privileged for adding the GT Cup - Great Bay Race to the inaugural calendar of Sro GT Cup, which begins and ends with the two largest motorized sports events in China. We already have a strong working relationship with the GT Cup - Great Bay Race, which has become the most significant race for GT4 cars in Asia. Its inclusion in the 2025 calendar of the SRO underlines the size of our ambition for this new national series. ” High interest The SRO GT Cup debut season starts in March at China's Formula 1 Grand Prix in Shanghai, before moving to the Zhuhai International Circuit - a place previously visited by SRO in BPR times and the FIA ​​GT Championship - where two 30 minutes races are planned. This is followed by the new Citadine Circuit of Beijing, which will host the GT World Challenge Asia on the same weekend, before the big end of the Sro GT Cup season, scheduled for a month later at the Guide Circuit in Macao. The enthusiasm surrounding this competition is evident. As Benjamin Franassovici said, “This is reflected in the number of consultations and registration for the full season we have received since the release of the championship, just before Christmas. The demand has exceeded our expectations. ” Up to 28 cars will be able to compete in the season end event on the streets of Macau, with places to be assigned based on the classification after the second round of the championship, which is scheduled for the Zhuhai Permanent Circuit. All pilots with “bronze” or “silver” classifications attributed by the FIA ​​are eligible to compete in this competition, as long as they use approved cars from the GT4 class. To attract brands, the results of SRO GT Cup races will tell the SRO GT4 builders ranking, a title attributed to the brand with better performance in the GT4 category at the end of each season. SRO GT CUP joins its Asian equivalent, Japan Cup, in a list that also includes continental and national competitions in Europe, America and Australia.
